Hi,

I am invoking junit tests programmatically. Gotto generate the reports as
well. For that purpose I have added XMLJUnitResultFormatter (from ant-junit)
as a listener to the TestResult. i get the following runtime error: 

 

        java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError: junit/framework/TestListener

 

at the statement: 

XMLJUnitResultFormatter resultFormatter = new XMLJUnitResultFormatter();

 

However following statement runs fine:

TestListener listener = new TestRunner(); //both are junit framework classes
and are accessible.

 

This means that the problem is when ant-junit class XMLJUnitResultFormatter
tries to access TestListener. 

 

Any ideas/suggestions?

 

Cheers

yogesh

Thanks for the reply, Jeff. I was looking at Spring a little today and
noticed they had a PropertiesFactoryBean. If I can convince my
managers to let me use Spring I could do something like:

<bean id="appProperites" class="package.AppProperties">
   <property name="source">
      <bean class="org.springframework...PropertiesFactoryBean">
         <property name="location">
            <value>classpath:app.properties</value>
         </property>
      </bean>
   </property>
</bean>

<bean id="otherBean" class="MyBean">
   <property name="appProperties">
      <ref local="appProperties"/>
   </property>
</bean>

With this, your suggestion of injecting the AppProperties into the
dependant objects becomes a breeze, making my testing life easier. I
can create a Properties object in my setUp() and set it into the
AppProperties, then set the AppProperties into my other objects.

Thanks again for the reply.

Michael.


--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Jeff Grigg" <jeffgrigg@c...> wrote:
> --- "Michael" <mkoss917@y...> wrote:
> > [...] a class called AppProperties. This class has a lot
> > of static methods on it for loading properties files and
> > getting properties back out:
> > [...]
> > This scenario is not very testable. I like the idea of a
> > static class to pull application properties from, but it
> > makes testing more difficult. I could load the AppProperties
> > object in the setUp (that is my solution to get it working
> > until I get better suggestions), but it seems like the app
> > should be designed a little differently.
> 
> The AppProperties methods could use a private static member to do 
> the detailed work.  And then you could use MockObject, during 
> testing, to control the static member object's behavior.
> 
> This can quickly lead to AppProperties being a Singleton.  That's 
> OK; the tests can swap in a MockObject in setUp and clear or reset 
> it on tearDown.
> 
> Singleton is not ideal, but it can be refactored later to remove the 
> Singleton-ness.
> 
> > How would something like this be handled in IoC (DI) projects? 
> 
> Other objects would accept an AppProperties instance in their 
> constructor or in a "set" method, and keep it in a local variable.  
> You can migrate from Singleton to this pattern, over time.
